title: Heinz History Center - Wikipedia
content:
[Jump to content](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#bodyContent) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Wiki_Loves_Monuments_Logo_notext.svg/70px-Wiki_Loves_Monuments_Logo_notext.svg.png)\\ Photograph a historic site, help Wikipedia, and win a prize. Participate in the world's largest photography competition this month!Learn more\\ [Coordinates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system "Geographic coordinate system"): ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/WMA_button2b.png/20px-WMA_button2b.png)[40°26′48″N79°59′32″W﻿ / ﻿40.4466°N 79.9922°W﻿ / 40.4466; -79.9922](https://geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Heinz_History_Center¶ms=40.4466_N_79.9922_W_region:US-PA_type:landmark) From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia History Museum in Pennsylvania, U.S. | [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/d7/Senator_John_Heinz_History_Center.svg/290px-Senator_John_Heinz_History_Center.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Senator_John_Heinz_History_Center.svg) | | [![Heinz History Center is located in Pennsylvania](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/USA_Pennsylvania_location_map.svg/250px-USA_Pennsylvania_location_map.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:USA_Pennsylvania_location_map.svg "Heinz History Center is located in Pennsylvania")
![Heinz History Center](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/20px-Red_pog.svg.png)
Location within Pennsylvania | Heinz History Center **The Senator John Heinz History Center**, an affiliate of the [Smithsonian Institution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smithsonian_Institution "Smithsonian Institution"),[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-1) is the largest history [museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum "Museum") in the [Commonwealth of Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pennsylvania "Pennsylvania"), United States. Named after [U.S. Senator](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Senator "U.S. Senator") [H. John Heinz III](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H._John_Heinz_III "H. John Heinz III") (1938–1991) from Pennsylvania, it is located in the [Strip District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strip_District,_Pittsburgh "Strip District, Pittsburgh") of [Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh,_Pennsylvania "Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania"). The Heinz History Center is a 275,000-square-foot (25,500 m2)[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-opening-2) educational institution "that engages and inspires a diverse audience with links to the past, understanding in the present, and guidance for the future by preserving regional history and presenting the American experience with a [Western Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Pennsylvania "Western Pennsylvania") connection."[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-:0-3) In 2024, the Heinz History Center was named the best history museum in the United States by readers of _[USA Today](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USA_Today "USA Today")_ as part of their annual Readers' Choice poll.[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-4) ## Senator John Heinz History Center \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Heinz_History_Center&action=edit§ion=1 "Edit section: Senator John Heinz History Center")\] [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/HistoryCener_from_Strip_District.JPG/250px-HistoryCener_from_Strip_District.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:HistoryCener_from_Strip_District.JPG) The Heinz History Center seen from the [Strip District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strip_District,_Pittsburgh "Strip District, Pittsburgh") in Pittsburgh in July 2007 In 1879, a club called Old Residents of Pittsburgh and Western Pennsylvania was founded. In 1884, leaders changed the organization's name to the [Historical Society of Western Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Historical_Society_of_Western_Pennsylvania "Historical Society of Western Pennsylvania") (HSWP); it has been operating continuously since then and is the Pittsburgh region's oldest cultural organization.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-:0-3) HSWP began the tradition of interpreting public history in 1911, organizing the centennial of [steamboat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steamboat "Steamboat") navigation in Pittsburgh. In 1955, it led the organization of the city's bicentennial celebration. During its early years, HSWP leaders held meetings in homes and churches, but in 1893, were granted space for the organization's archives at the new [Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Library_of_Pittsburgh "Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh") in the [Oakland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oakland_(Pittsburgh) "Oakland (Pittsburgh)") neighborhood.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-:0-3) By 1914, HSWP had its own building on Bigelow Boulevard. It operated there until 1996, when its expanded quarters in the renovated historic warehouse were completed in Pittsburgh's [Strip District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strip_District,_Pittsburgh "Strip District, Pittsburgh").[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-:0-3) The Society celebrated the opening of the new museum by hosting an inaugural gala there on April 26, 1996, for 900 guests.\[ _[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_\] In 2004, the Smithsonian wing was completed, adding a gallery for changing exhibitions from the [Smithsonian Institution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smithsonian_Institution "Smithsonian Institution"), a Special Collections Gallery, an Education Center, and the Western Pennsylvania Sports Museum.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-5) The History Center is named for [John Heinz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Heinz "John Heinz"), a former U.S. Senator from Pennsylvania who died in a 1991 plane crash.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-opening-2) ### Architecture \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Heinz_History_Center&action=edit§ion=2 "Edit section: Architecture")\] The century-old Chautauqua Lake Ice Company building was renovated and adapted by the Pittsburgh office of the architecture firm of [Bohlin Cywinski Jackson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bohlin_Cywinski_Jackson "Bohlin Cywinski Jackson"), who did the design and oversaw construction. The interior was designed to show off the building's features, as well as create spaces for exhibits and support space. The museum building is an exhibit in its own right.[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-6) ### Interior and contents \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Heinz_History_Center&action=edit§ion=3 "Edit section: Interior and contents")\] The History Center features the Western Pennsylvania Sports Museum, Detre Library & Archives, and six floors of permanent and changing exhibitions that tell the story of Western Pennsylvania.[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-7) The History Center features permanent exhibitions including: - _Pittsburgh: A Tradition of Innovation_ \- celebrates 250 years of Western Pennsylvania's significant contributions to the world, from Dr. [Jonas Salk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jonas_Salk "Jonas Salk")'s discovery of the polio vaccine to the invention of the [Big Mac](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Mac "Big Mac").[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-8) - _Senator John Heinz: A Western Pennsylvania Legacy_ \- details the life and legacy of one of Pittsburgh's most beloved philanthropists and politicians.[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-9) - _Clash of Empires: The British, French, & Indian War, 1754-1763_ \- explores the origins, development, and aftermath of the global French and Indian War.[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-10) - _From Slavery to Freedom_ \- explores more than 250 years of African American history, from 18th century Africa to 21st century Western Pennsylvania.[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-11) - _Rediscovering Lewis & Clark: A Journey with the Rooney Family_ \- traces the path of Lewis and Clark's expedition beginning in Pittsburgh.[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-12) - _Glass: Shattering Notions_ \- showcases Pittsburgh's reign as America's "glass city" and the history of the region’s first industry.[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-13) - _Heinz_ \- chronicles the history of the H.J. Heinz Company.[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-14) - _Visible Storage_ \- provides a behind-the-scenes look at more than 1,200 objects in the museum's collection.[\[15\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-15) - _Special Collections_ _Gallery_ \- houses artifacts illustrating the rich ethnic history and corporate fabric of the Pittsburgh region.[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-16) The gallery also features original set pieces and props from [Mister Rogers' Neighborhood](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mister_Rogers%27_Neighborhood "Mister Rogers' Neighborhood"), which was filmed in Pittsburgh.[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-17) ## Western Pennsylvania Sports Museum at the History Center \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Heinz_History_Center&action=edit§ion=4 "Edit section: Western Pennsylvania Sports Museum at the History Center")\] Located in the Smithsonian wing of the Senator John Heinz History Center, the Western Pennsylvania Sports Museum spans 20,000 square feet (1,900 m2) of exhibit space over two floors. The "museum within a museum" captures the Pittsburgh region's evolution and influence as a sports leader over more than a century, from amateur to pro and across the spectrum of sports. The Sports Museum captures tales of Pittsburgh sports through hundreds of artifacts, more than 70 hands-on interactive exhibits, and 20 audio-visual programs. Select artifacts include [Franco Harris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franco_Harris "Franco Harris")' " [Immaculate Reception](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Immaculate_Reception "Immaculate Reception")" cleats; [Mario Lemieux](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mario_Lemieux "Mario Lemieux")'s hockey skates; [Satchel Paige](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satchel_Paige "Satchel Paige")'s baseball glove; the pitching rubber from the 1960 World Series; [Billy Conn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Billy_Conn "Billy Conn")'s boxing gloves and light heavyweight champion belt; [Arnold Palmer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arnold_Palmer "Arnold Palmer")'s sweater and golf bag; [Chip Ganassi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chip_Ganassi "Chip Ganassi")'s 2000 Indy 500-winning race car; the "Ultimate Steelers Fan's Car;" the [Homestead](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homestead,_Pennsylvania "Homestead, Pennsylvania") women swimmers [Olympic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympic_Games "Olympic Games") medals from the 1920s and 1930s; and hundreds of [Pittsburgh Pirates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates "Pittsburgh Pirates") [baseball cards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baseball_cards "Baseball cards"). ## Detre Library & Archives at the History Center \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Heinz_History_Center&action=edit§ion=5 "Edit section: Detre Library & Archives at the History Center")\] The History Center's Detre Library & Archives is an extensive scholarly resource documenting 250 years of life in Western Pennsylvania. The collection includes books, manuscripts, photographs, maps, atlases, newspapers, films, recordings, and other memorabilia.[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-18) ## Meadowcroft Rockshelter and Historic Village \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Heinz_History_Center&action=edit§ion=6 "Edit section: Meadowcroft Rockshelter and Historic Village")\] Main article: [Meadowcroft Rockshelter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meadowcroft_Rockshelter "Meadowcroft Rockshelter") The History Center also operates [Meadowcroft Rockshelter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meadowcroft_Rockshelter "Meadowcroft Rockshelter"), a world-renowned [archaeological](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Archaeological "Archaeological") site south of Pittsburgh near [Washington County](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_County,_Pennsylvania "Washington County, Pennsylvania")'s [Avella](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avella,_Pennsylvania "Avella, Pennsylvania") community. The Rockshelter is the oldest site of human habitation in North America, with evidence of humans living there for nearly 19,000 years.[\[19\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-19) The site was named a [National Historic Landmark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Historic_Landmark "National Historic Landmark") in 2005.[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-20) The site also includes a recreated 16th century Monongahela Indian Village and 1770s Frontier Trading Post.[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-21) Adjacent to the Rockshelter is a historic village featuring 19th century structures relocated to the site. The History Center operates this as a living museum, with re-enactors recreating rural life in the 19th century Upper Ohio Valley.[\[22\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-22) ## Fort Pitt Museum \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Heinz_History_Center&action=edit§ion=7 "Edit section: Fort Pitt Museum")\] Main article: [Fort Pitt Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Pitt_Museum "Fort Pitt Museum") Since 2010, the History Center has operated the [Fort Pitt Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Pitt_Museum "Fort Pitt Museum"), a two-floor, 12,000-square-foot (1,100 m2) museum located at [Point State Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Point_State_Park "Point State Park").[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-23)[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-:1-24) The museum tells the story of Western Pennsylvania’s pivotal role during the [French and Indian War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_and_Indian_War "French and Indian War"), the [American Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Revolution "American Revolution"), and as the birthplace of Pittsburgh.[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_note-:1-24) ## References \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Heinz_History_Center&action=edit§ion=8 "Edit section: References")\] 01. **[^](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_History_Center#cite_ref-1 "Jump up")**["About"](https://web.archive.org/web/20141231083504/http://www.heinzhistorycenter.org/about).
